remixed_from.author: Saf
remixed_from.title: i3v 10" Prusa Makerfarm X-Carriage Stock Style

description.text:
Update 1/18/2016
I printed this carriage in PETG at 50% infill & have been using it for over a week without any problems. last night I printed a 14 hour print of a Delta Vertex. The carriage took over 5 hours to print. I included a photo of that carriage installed. I modified this X-carriage design this past summer. I named it a happy x-carriage because it initially had a smile carved in the back plate. That design did not seem as functional as this, but it still seems happy. This was created with openscad. I used Draftsight to create the 2d geometry & TurboCAD to generate the ledge around the edge using the railsweep command. I have been sidetracked on some other projects, so I have printed out this final version, but have printed & tested versions similar to this. Thought I would go ahead and upload this in case someone else would like to try this part. With the added holes & triangle shaped cuts on the side, I believe this will help venting heat as well as cutting down on some vibration. I also added my x-carriage Belt clamp which is used by the openscad program when drawing this assembled to visualize potential interferences. There are 3 main options for printing this part. You can add:

  • Ears to help keep it stuck to the print bed.

  • 1/8" brass bar cutouts to keep it stiff in case you want to try using PETG instead of ABS
    With the added holes for ventilation & the brass, my hope is to be able to print this in PETG

  • A cutout for ABL servo
    Dimensions for this were taken from clough42 part: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:335632
    • Print one of these STL files or adjust the openscad file to your needs:
    i3V_X-Carriage_rev30_repaired.stl
    i3V_X-Carriage_WithEars_rev30_repaired.stl
    i3V_X-CarriageNoEars_BrassCuts_rev30_repaired.stl
    i3V_X-CarriageWithABLMount_rev30_repaired.stl I plan to use 50% infill for this print.

title: Geeetech G2/G2s Universal Spider for E3D v5/v6 and PEEK J-Heads

description.header: Geeetech G2/G2s Rostock Spider - Universal Snap-Fit
description.text:
This is a replacement spider for the Geeetech G2/G2s Rostock Mini Delta printers.
This spider uses a snap-fit lock mechanism, allowing quick replacement and maintenance of the heads.
Heads are inserted from the bottom, and the lock is applied to the groove mount from the top of the spider.  Press the lock into the slot to complete assembly.
The nozzle spread is 30mm by default, to support the default E3D hotend fans.

Printer:

Geeetech G2/G2s Rostock Mini Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.125mm

Infill:

23%

Notes: This should be an easy print using the 'universal_spider_plate.stl' file, which will print the spider, both J-Head (4.75mm groovemount) x1 and x2 locks, and both E3D v5/v6 (6mm groovemount) x1 and x2 locks. The other files are provided for people that only want to print the parts that they need - make sure to rotate them as needed for printing.

Before assembling onto your printer, make sure to trim away any flashing, and ensure that the locks fit correctly with the hotends installed. The tolerances are tight, and may require a bit of sanding to get the correct fit. The locks should snap into place with less than 10kg of force, but should hold the hotends in place if the spider is inverted or shaken. Trim any flashing, and verify that your have a tight (but not forced) press-fit connection before mounting the spider. Insert hot-end through the bottom of the spider. Clamp hot end locks around the hot end. Push hotend and lock assembly into spider for a secure snap-in fit. Should require no more than 10kg of force - if it's too tight, trim flashing from the lock. Dual hotends are inserted from the bottom - both at the same time. Clamp on the rear hotend lock first, to hold the hot ends in place, then clamp on the front lock. Press the locked hotends into place. Lower the spider to Z=0, and gently adjust the press-fit to align the nozzles of both hot ends.

Many thanks to Geeetech and E3D, which both provided 3D sketches and models on their web sites, which allowed me to test-fit this design in simulation. Sources to this and other of my Geeetech G2/G2s modifications can be found at my Geeetech Modifications GitHub page.

title: MakerGear Z-knob with Crank and Stop

description.text: Tim Edwards made a very nice and extremely useful attachment for the MakerGear Z-knob that drops on top and can function as both a crank for the Z-axis as well as a stop that automatically ejects if you forget to remove it when you start a print. It's a little bulky since it goes over the factory Z-knob. I combined the current MakerGear low-profile Z-knob with the ramp and post from Tim's cap to make a one-piece knob that's a little smaller and has fewer parts but retains all the great features. The factory knob has a metal insert that was press-fit inside it. I simply sawed a little slit on each side of my factory knob then cracked it in-half with a screwdriver to remove the insert. I then re-used it in the new/improved knob. I used a socket from my tool set to allow me to squeeze it together in the vise without crushing the ramp and post. I also added a small chamfer to the top of the post so that the lever drops on more easily. Works great. This replacement knob uses the same crank handle from Tim's version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:934680 I recommend printing the crank in a color other than black so that you don't keep misplacing it like I do with mine.

title: 3D Printed Rocket with Forward Swept Fins

description.text: My first thingy!  Want to fly a rocket?  Need one that looks cool?  Well here is a 3D rocket that actually flies (motor not included).

Update (2015_5_6): rsilvers has made an improved nose cone
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:803464 Update: added a new payload ("payload2"). It has the built in rail guid and parachute mount near the bottom. You will have to tie on the parachute then screw on the payload. Hopefully it doesn't block to charge that blows the parachute. This is a 3D printable rocket that takes a Estes B motor (18x70mm). I recommend about a 4 to 6 second delay on this. Previous tests were done with a 0 second delay motor and (needless to say) deployed the chute too early. When printing, be mindful of the height of the models. I found out after 3 failed prints that I needed 124mm of height to complete these so I needed to reburn my Prusa firmware. With a 1 or 2mm brim the motor holder printed very nicely. I made my chute out of a Kroger bag, some string, and hotglue. A rubber band glued into a paper fold is used in the payload section to keep the nosecone and chute connected. I posted a picture of it. The rubberband absorbs the shock of the chute deployment. Glue a straw to the side so that it acts as a guide rail. To launch, just buy the motors on the internet or at a local hobby shop (look up Estes B motors). Use a stiff wire as a guide rail and slide rocket on. Wire up the ignition plugs that come with the motors using aligator clips. To fire, simply tough the end leads to a 9V batter. Had 3 good launchs with the prototype! Have fun and be safe!!!

Design concept: RAPIRO - The Humanoid Robot and Gundam This is an upgrade version of my MobBob V2 Remix robot. MobBob is a smart phone controlled robot. By harnessing the power of your smart phone, MobBob is a walking, talking robot with voice recognition and computer vision that you can build for around $35. I will be continuing to extend his features over time. I want MobBob to be a companion robot that everyone can afford and have fun with. You can see videos of MobBob V2 Remix upgrade in action here:
https://youtu.be/8nO0kziJvsk - 3D Design
https://youtu.be/ehrsIDJcVZY - Test #1
https://youtu.be/j0oz8OPYhNs - Test #2
https://youtu.be/5z4Ps11t-vE - Test #3
.....
Coming soon!! The main aims of the V2 remix were to: Support standard 9g servos [previously I was using Tower Pro SG90 servos]
Make everything easier to assemble [no more need for glue]
Make it easier to adapt/modify for other phones. The new bracket system made it easier to exchange a new phone / the battery holder. Also, in my V2 Remix Upgrade build, I'm also using the Arduino Nano instead of the DIY Nano shield, so the entire build is smaller and tidier. :) MobBob V2 Remix Upgrade uses the same software as the original RAPIRO. You can find the latest Arduino code here: https://github.com/Ishiwatari/RAPIRO
The modified code is included: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1235865 You can download the latest version of the Android from Google Play - it is free, ad-free, and without IAP:
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.github.luzhuomi.rapicommand You can find more detailed build and wiring instructions here:
...coming soon... The parts that you need to print: 1 x Leg Left

1 x Arduino Nano ATmega328 [see note below]
1 x HM-10 BLE Bluetooth 4.0 CC2540 CC2541 Serial Wireless Module [or HC-05]
1 x 5V Micro USB 1A Lithium Battery Charging Board [see note below]

2 x M3 15mm [for Jacket]

12 x M2 15mm [for Arm and Hand]
[Note: I got the servos, Arduino Nano, Bluetooth Module and Battery for under $30.] Arduino Nano: This is a small, Arduino compatible ATmega328 board with DIY extension board. MobBob V2 app connects to the Bluetooth module using its Bluetooth LE service. The app to support other Bluetooth cards. Battery Extender: You can use other batteries that provide 5V with a steady current. If you use other batteries, you may need to adapt the battery rack for your battery's size.
Use 18650 Lithium Battery Charging Board With Protection Charger Module and Step Up Boost Module 3.7V to 5V for Smart Phone
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1235749 Smart Phone: You can use other Android Smart Phones with This app.
You do not need to adapt the size of the phone holder for your phone. The app has been successfully tested with Nexus and Samsung, LG phones, but should work on other Android phones. Instructions: Print all the required parts
Get all the non-3D printed parts
Assemble as per the photos - I'll be writing some more detailed instructions on my website soon!
Install the Arduino code from the GitHub link in the description - You will need to update the Arduino pins in the code to match yours, and probably update the centering values for the servos.
Install the Android app from the link in the description. Have fun! If you hit any problems, please post a question on this website: [http://www.rapiro.com], here, or on YouTube channel. A few people have built RAPIRO now, so there are people around who can help. Coming soon update!! The open source Mobbob V2 software and hardware is free and made with love. Please show your level of support with a voluntary donation. Donate:
https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=RDN7ZGAVFS5UE

modified by Zalophus on the command line, enter:
// #M1 - robot will move forward
// #M2 - robot will move backward
// #M3 - robot will turn right
// #M4 - robot will turn left
// #M5 - robot will raise his hand and wave the left hand. LED will become green and flashing
// #M6 - robot will lower his left hand. LED will become Yellow
// #M7 - robot will move both arm and contract his hands. LED will become Blue
// #M8 - robot will wave goodbye with his left arm. LED will become RED.
// #M9 - robot will raise its right arm and move its waist. LED will become BLUE
// #M0 - robot will go to initial position CAPS LOCK is important when you input a command via the serial monitor..
Reading through the source code.
Each movement of the preset (# M1 ~ # M9), consists of pattern of 8 frames.
Each frame is defined values ​​uint8_t type sixteen (motion).
This can be changed modifying the number of frame per pattern.MAXFN
Lets take #M0 for example: uint8_t motion[MAXMN][MAXFN][16]={
{ // 0 Stop
{ 90, 90, 0,130, 90,180, 50, 90, 90, 90, 90, 90, 0, 0,255, 10},
{ 90, 90, 0,130, 90,180, 50, 90, 90, 90, 90, 90, 0, 0, 0, 0},
{ 90, 90, 0,130, 90,180, 50, 90, 90, 90, 90, 90, 0, 0, 0, 0},
{ 90, 90, 0,130, 90,180, 50, 90, 90, 90, 90, 90, 0, 0, 0, 0},
{ 90, 90, 0,130, 90,180, 50, 90, 90, 90, 90, 90, 0, 0, 0, 0},
{ 90, 90, 0,130, 90,180, 50, 90, 90, 90, 90, 90, 0, 0, 0, 0},
{ 90, 90, 0,130, 90,180, 50, 90, 90, 90, 90, 90, 0, 0, 0, 0},
{ 90, 90, 0,130, 90,180, 50, 90, 90, 90, 90, 90, 0, 0, 0, 0}
}, I put numbers so you can visualy make sense of what a pattern is, and what a frame contain.
Movements consist of pattern. Pattern are made of frames. Each frame contrain the rotation angle of every servo, the values of the RGB LED and a Time to perform the action. Head horizontal rotation angle (Head yaw) (left) 180 <---> 0 (right)
Hip horizontal rotation angle (Waist yaw) (left) 180 <---> 0 (right)
Right shoulder up and down angle (R Shoulder yaw) (bottom) 0 <---> 180 (above)
Open right shoulder angle (R Shoulder pitch) (closed) 90 <---> 180 (open)
Right hand opening and closing angle (R Hand grip) (closed) 50 <---> 110 (open)
Left shoulder up and down angle (L Shoulder yaw) (bottom) 180 <---> 0 (top)
Open left shoulder angle (L Shoulder pitch) (closed) 90 <-> 0 (open)
Left hand opening and closing angle (L Hand grip) (closed) 130 <---> 70 (open)
Right foot horizontal rotation angle (R Foot yaw) (left) 0 <---> 180 (right)
Twist angle of the right foot ankle (R Foot pitch) () 0 <---> 180 (outside)
Left foot horizontal rotation angle (L Foot yaw) (left) 0 <---> 180 (right)
Twist angle of the left foot ankle (R Foot pitch) (within) 180 <---> 0 (outside)
Red component of the eye (R) 0 <---> 255
Green component of the eye (G) 0 <---> 255
Blue component of the eye (B) 0 <---> 255 Here are some other helpful commands that can be used to control the LED and each servos individually. LED CODE sample // #PR000G255B000T010 - MAX GREEN COLOR
R,G,B values between 0 and 255
T is the time component to get to desired color LIMBS MOVEMENT
Sxx refers to one of the 12 motors (from S00 to S11),
A000 up to A180 is the angle where to servo incline,
Txxx is the time to perform the movement.
you can combine two commands, i tried more but it didn’t work.. // #PS00A000T010#PS00A180T010 - full head movement from side to side
// #PS01A000T010#PS01A180T010 - Waist
// #PS02A000T010#PS02A180T010 - r Shoulder
// #PS03A050T010#PS03A180T010 - r Arm
// #PS04A030T010#PS04A140T010 - r HAND
// #PS05A000T010#PS05A180T010 - l Shoulder
// #PS06A130T010#PS06A010T010 – l Arm
// #PS07A030T010#PS07A180T010 – l hand
// #PS08A000T010#PS08A180T010 - r Foot yaw
// #PS09A000T010#PS09A180T010 - r Foot pitch
// #PS10A000T010#PS10A180T010 - l Foot yaw
// #PS11A000T010#PS11A180T010 - l Foot pitch // #PS00A090S01A090S02A000S03A090S04A090S05A180S06A090S07A090S08A090S09A090S10A090S11A090R000G000B000T005

While it's not the usual representation, it's topologically equivalent! (And almost fits on your finger too!) Made as a statement to the other Klein Bottles on Thingiverse that there are formulas for these things which aren't quite as rotund. I originally planned to have the Klein Bottle itself on here but realized that
(1) it's a surface, which would require it to be thickened, which is something Mathematica doesn't to on export (plus inside-outside problem)
(2) Skeinforge might throw up on the self-intersections. So for now, Thingiverse has to be content with its short Klein bottles and this... bracelet?

description.text: A Christmas light organizer.

• Buy a 1kg spool of your favorite 3d printing filament.
    • Avoid smaller spools like those from taulman.
  • Select the load program on your printer
    • If you don't have a feed program use the attached gcode *
  • Feed in filament
  • Wait until spool is empty
  • Discard extruded plastic
  • Spool Christmas lights onto newly empty spool.
  • Repeat from step 1 until all your Christmas lights are organized.

description.header: *: Do not under any circumstances actually use this gcode.

I hate the dials that come with the ships. My fingers are too big, and they tend to slip right out of my hands as I'm trying to spin them. This is my second iteration in my attempt to improve on the original design to make them both easier to use, and easier to see what the other movements on your dial are.

comments.text: cool! i want these!!! i don't have access to a 3D printer. how can i get these?
comments.author: delroz

comments.text: Honestly, I made a far superior version out of clear acrylic that I've been using instead now. Do you have access to a laser cutter?
comments.author: delroz

comments.text: No unfortunately not. I only stumbled upon this site by accident. Do you know someone who is willing to do it for me?
comments.author: jebleez

comments.text: Morning Jebleez,
comments.author: FerenGreydog

comments.text: Go for it! :)
comments.author: FerenGreydog

comments.text: Love this design.  Simple and elegant.  Haven't printed one yet, so how tight is the fit?   Is it likely to come apart while I'm turning the dial, and will it "slip" between placement and reveal?  Also, how do you identify which dial is for which ship type, other than looking for the small identifier on the dial?
comments.author: nestyr

comments.text:
No worries! I'm always looking for ways to improve my designs! It's actually pretty tight. I've used one of these with Poe for the last month or so, and it's stayed together nicely. It's just tight enough that it won't rotate by itself.
I know it sounds kind of crappy, but I just sharpie the ship name on the plastic. If I wanted to take the time, I could create an embossing on the design and make one for every ship, but since I just play casually, it's not that big of a deal to me.
comments.author: nestyr

comments.text:
So are these easy enough to take apart that I could just get 8 and swap the dials to the ones I want to use?
On the identification issue, is the plastic smooth enough to use a dry erase or wet erase marker to erase and re-mark the dials when I do swap them? Alternatively I was thinking to just use a bookmark type post-it to identify which is which.
comments.author: jebleez

comments.text: They come apart as easily as the pegs that come with the dials, so... not too easy, and not too hard.

comments.text: Cool, Thanks for getting back to me on that :)

comments.text:
I love the Makita but you need to make sure the version available to you has the collet sizes appropriate for your mill bits. The version available in the US only comes with a 1/4" collet. I wanted to have the option to use 1/8" mill bits so I bought an adapter from http://www.elairecorp.com/makitaroutercollets.html. They are expensive at $25, but have very high quality and a very low "runout" . I think I have read that the EU versions of the Makita use a different spindle interior dimension and these adaptors may not fit.
SteveC

remixed_from.title: Print Cooling Fan System for MakerFarm Prusa i3 and i3v

title: Print Cooling Fan Shroud Mount for mk8 Extruder

description.text:
I wanted to add a print cooling fan to my cheap, Chinese Prusa i3 with a mk8 extruder and basic hot end.  The fan shroud i give remix credit to looked to be just the ticket.  This mount allows the fan and shroud to mount to the extruder in place of the heat sink fan spacers that came with the unit.  It allows adequate clearance between the extruder, the print, and the fan shroud.  It comes close enough to centering the shroud on the nozzle for my taste.
Printed in PLA with supports and super slow since without it, my printer was garbage at overhangs at higher speeds.  
Now i am just waiting on the china post to get my fan to me.  Hopefully this does the trick.

comments.author: hkayaprager

comments.text: Hey hkayaprager! You will need to swap the filament color on the print of the MCRN piece. Start your print with a color for the back plate and monitor it closely. As soon as you see the MCRN letters start to form on the plate, pause & swap in a new filament color for the lettering. description.text: A deadmau5 inspired keychain thingy!

Printer:

Vertex

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

This is a mechanical scoop. It can be powered by an arduino and a servomotor. You only need to print it and assemble it. It opens by gravity and it is closed by the servomotor, no need for springs to keep it open
It can carry sugar, sand and other granulated elements. (I have not tested it with water, but I don't think it will work.
I would have included some set of pulleys to hang the scoop, but when I tried to print them it didn't work well, instead a set of LEGO (R) pulleys worked better.

For assembly To build the mechanism you will need some nails you can find at home. The upper holes can be filled with small glass nails and it will work just fine. For the lower ones anything that fits will do.
If something doesn't fit it's because the printer isn't as precise as it needs to be. If that happens you can fix it with some sandpaper or with an abrasive file.
You can connect the mechanism to the servomotor by a string
Questions If you have any concerns about this scoop please e-mail me at: [email protected]

remixed_from.author: doctek
remixed_from.title: Jim's Flying Motor Mount Dual Extruder

title: In Action: Jim's Flying Motor Mount Dual Extruder

description.text:
Lots to see here, folks! The video https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_detailpage&v=gR1vrykA90E shows http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34821 in action, printing its first version of the Dual Extruder Calibration Piece (soon to be another Thing). It's taken nearly eight months of work since the original posting, but the dual extruders are now working reliably. Building this dual extruder is still not a project for beginners, but the careful builder will be rewarded with a compact dual extruder that mounts directly on an X-carriage ÃƒÂ¢Ã‚Â€Ã‚Â“ no bowden arrangement. The complete build instructions are in the Instructable that accompanied the original Thing. Posted here are the details that have evolved during the course of making this work. It's worth noting http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:93513 is an X-carriage for a Prusa that will mount Jim's Flying Motor Mount Dual Extruder. Included with that is a fan mount for the nozzle cooling fans. If you have a Prusa, you can get going quickly. These pieces were used for all my development so far. I have also designed a part cooling duct that I will post soon. My initial work did not use it, but I will mount it now for all future printing. One of the first challenges I faced was that Marlin for the Printrboard did not fully support dual extruders. Fortunately, I found a version of Marlin which included support for dual extruders, but it was for an earlier Marlin version and had not been merged. So I merged it into Lincomatic's Printrboard version. I will post this to Thingiverse so anyone who wants it can use it. The modified Marlin can independently control the dual extruders (independent temperature settings and stepper settings), but there was still some effort involved in making Pronterface handle dual extruders in a reasonable manner. Instructions for using Pronterface to control dual extrusion will be included with the Marlin code posting. Once I could extrude plastic independently using Marlin and Pronterface, I needed a way to calibrate the extruders. So I designed a simple calibration block in OpenSCAD. Of course, the next step was to slice it so that the two extruders were used to print it. Fortunately, Slic3r now has the capability to handle dual extruders, either printing support material or two different colors. Full instructions for creating the calibration block and slicing it with Slic3r will be the subject of another Thing. With calibration working, the next challenge was to try longer prints to see what problems might occur. And, yup, some occurred. The main problem was that the motors heated up. While the heat did not cause any permanent deformation of the PLA extruder bodies, it softened them enough to allow them to flex (I think) and the drive gears disengaged. This caused the flow of plastic to stop. Four possible solutions occurred to me:
Print the extruder bodies in ABS which is more heat resistant.
Put cooling fans on the motors.
Use a hypocycloid reduction gear http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:79231 on each motor.
Re-design the extruder body to increase its strength and rigidity. ABS bodies were offered for testing, and so it was easy to try them. The results were mixed: While the flexing problem was completely solved, the motors still heated up and started missing steps. This might have been happening earlier, and not noticed. Putting on the cooling fans http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32994 cured the heat problem completely. The motors barely heat up now. So I have not tried the other two solutions. I doubt if making the bodies stronger would help, since the ABS bodies didn't defect and it doesn't help the heating problem. Using the hypocycloid gear reducers would work (the motors run cooler since they run at higher rpm more efficiently and heat up less), but would complicate things and require development effort. The only down side is that the cooling fans take up some height from the build area. So with the fans in place, Jim's FMM Dual works reliably. Not to say there won't be any tweaking, but it's ready for use. Build one, get the tools and techniques as I post them, and explore the world of dual extrusion. Have fun! Future work.
For the PLA I was using, I set the Retraction Length (on the Printer Settings/ Extruder 1 page) to 5mm and the Extra Length on Restart to 1mm. (Same for Extruder 2.) This seemed to give decent results, but can certainly stand more tuning. I haven't experimented with settings on that page yet.

Mostly, this is just about the operation of the dual extruder and the plans for future things. Stay tuned for the other pieces!  
But I have included a version of the body without the support structure for easier printing. This was derived directly from the OpenSCAD file.

comments.text: There is nothing about this design that will change the basic design rules for printing. The usual rule is that if you print with an overhang greater than 45 degrees, you will need support. YMMV. One thing this design offers is the option of using a different material for the support. comments.text: Jim, that looks really promising.  If you haven't tried yet, there is a Wipe module in Skeinforge that will take the extruder to a cleaning area, and wipe the nozzles.  You would probably want to cool the inactive nozzle during the cleaning, to prevent ooze.

I've since done more experiments using retract-during-layer-change (5mm retract / 1mm extra on restart) and greatly reduced the drool (ooze). I'm planning more experiments to tune things more, but I'm hoping not to need a wipe.

title: TPA3116 Poweramp Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A case for a TPA3116 power amplifier to go with the 6n3 preamp case found here. If you're not familiar with the TPA3116 chipamp I suggest you google it, great sounding little amp for the cost of a few coffees and my main amplifier now days. Of course you can use another amplifier board if you like... To build you'll need the items listed below, a solder iron and some basic soldering skills:
  • A TPA3116 board without volume/tone controls and soldered RCA connectors I would suggest either the highly praised board from Audiobah or the Yuan Jing black and blue board if you feel like modding.
  • A Mean Well RS-75-15 MW Power Supply 15V 5A search ebay for best price
  • M3 12mm screws

description.text: Because fezzes are cool, and I finally have a printer big enough to print wearable hats, tassels too. The stl is sized to fit my XL head. You might be able to print a kids version on a more standard size printer. The hat and tassel were printed with FoxSmart TPU. It is flexible enough to actually be comfortable, not to mention pretty well waterproof. We talked about this and a whole lot more on the 3D Printing Today podcast available on iTunes, or Stitcher radio learn more at http://www.threedprintingtoday.com/

Printer:

GIGANTOR

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.6mm layers 1mm nozzle

Infill:

none

Notes: Print with the top of the hat on the build plate with no infill and no roof. 2 floors and 1 wall. Continuous spiral mode gives the cleanest results. Clip off the little stub in the middle to form the hole for the tassel. After printing the tassel thread a piece of filament through the center hole and tie a stopper knot (gotta love TPU) then do the same with the hat.

Its a rough remake but works just as it was intended to from the beginning. Depending how you turn them. They should go into all corners and look good.
So 2 of each should be printed. New verson got the right lenght to the legs Uppdate: Been running the damps with a bunch of prints. And if you have the rigidbot standing on its own before on the table its a bigg improvment on noice. Since usually the table makes the vibrations worse.
The printer seems to wiggle with Y-axis movement but the tenis balls will not come off.
The best thing with it is that i get the printer higher of the table i got them on.

A small axe, suitable for a GJ Joe

I'm sure I'm not the first homebrewer to have this problem: My fermenter uses tri-clover style sanitary flanges. My gas system uses corny keg ball lock connectors. These are both pretty standard on modern homebrew setups. I want to push my beer out of my fermenter and into a corny keg using gas pressure. I need an adapter which, for some reason, no one makes. Luckily I have a 3d printer (several in fact). This thing has the right thread to take a corny keg ball lock gas post (threads are not standard across manufacturers so no guarantees here) and connects to a 1.5" tri-clover flange. Note that in this application the fitting is only holding 2-3psi of gas pressure, just enough to push the beer. The lid seal of the fermenter would vent any higher pressure. Using this adapter in any higher pressure system could cause severe injury, death and lawyers. We talked about this and a whole lot more on the 3D Printing Today podcast available on iTunes, or Stitcher radio learn more at http://www.threedprintingtoday.com/

Printer:

FlashForgeCreator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm layers

Infill:

100%

Notes: 0.1mm layers helps to print the threads cleanly. I printed it in TPU to make it strong. I recommend at least 4 shells and 100% infill. Remember this needs to be not only watertight, but gas tight as well.

title: Hanging LED Holder for 9 Volt Battery

description.text:
This is a simple holder for three 5mm, 3 Volt, LED's and a 9 Volt battery. It is design to be used with flat top LED's that have a wide angle of illumination (120 degrees). My original use for them was for hanging inside paper lanterns, but I'm sure it can be used to for a lot of other applications.  
Enjoy!

Note: The LEDs are connected in series with a 9 v battery.
  • Insert LEDs as shown on the drawing from the photo gallery.
  • Twist or solder together LED1 (+) with LED2 (-)
  • Twist or solder together LED2 (+) with LED3 (-)
  • Curl the wire of LED1 (-) so it fits nicely inside its cup. This is the negative (-) terminal for the battery.
  • Curl the wire of LED3 (+) so it fits nicely inside its cup. This is the positive (+) terminal for the battery.
  • Insert battery!

This is my second part. It is a box with tongue-groove joint. Its size can be customized, so you can create a kind of organizer for screws/nuts or electronic parts or any other things.
The base file is a OpenSCAD file, but I also include some STL examples.
Created with OpenSCAD (2015.03-2).

These parameters should be modified before creating STL file for each box: // base length bl=30; // at least 20mm size (external) of a 1x1 box // base height bh=12; box height (external) // box multiplications mx=1; my=2; Specify how big a single box should be (multiplication of a basic box) // tongue&groove elements xt = true; xg = true; yt = true; yg = true; Outer boxes probably should have no tongues or grooves. Here you can disable any of them

This is just a proof of concept,I ONLY use it for light duty milling such as PCB engraving,wood,plastic...etc,milling metal is NOT recommended,the only concern here is that the ball bearings does generate heat potentially it will melt the ABS cause the shaft out of balance and destroy the motor,so be careful.I am not responsible for any damage or injury if you make one and use it.

title: Groovemount plate for Greg's x-carriage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an aluminum plate that mounts on Greg's x-carriage. This could be made out of a lot of materials, but I milled this one out of 6061 .25" plate on a CNC mill. 
Using aluminum makes it act like a heatsink as well as a mounting plate, and keeps the top of the groovemount nice and cool, avoiding issues with melting extruder bodies (you folks making em out of PLA, imma look at you).

Be sure to get the groove TAB exactly 4.64 mm thick, as it will be either wobbly or impossible to assemble if it is too small or too big.
I am including only the dxf because there are plenty of plastic ones out there, and the heatsinking is the whole reason I made it.

title: Bezel for SainSmart LCD Keypad Shield for the Arduino

description.text: I designed this to dress up a project that used the SainSmart LCD Keypad Shield with and Arduino. The bezel itself prints pretty easily with very little support structure needed. The buttons are designed to be self-captivating (they just push in and stay). There are pilot holes for screwing down the LCD, but be sure to use spacers if necessary. As with anything, some adjustments may be necessary depending on the slop in the electrical components.
Use caution in cleaning up the button holes in the bezel, ream them too much and the buttons won't be self-captivating.

Notes: I made this with ABS, but any material will do. It doesn't carry any great stress, just keeping the rail of the rack from jumping out of a slot. Its possible that your rack will have a different size piece of wood, so print a small piece and check/adjust before printing the whole thing. Mine is just a hair under 10mm by 20mm. description.text:
If your like me then you've collected a lot of those small "wall warts" of the plug-in power supplies and always searching for the proper one to fit that new gizmo you just bought and now needs a fresh recharge to continue wasting your time with.  :0    Or that power supply that fits this tool you've about wore out building some of those gizmo's.
Well know that you've got a 3D printer you can print yourself up a bunch of these tags and always know which one fits what and may even save you from burning one or two of them up from over powering them.
There are two files. One is the first i printed and is the small hole one. I figured i'd upload it as well. It has a small hole that is real tight and want slide on the cord like the Large hole one may do. Either way there is a Small holed one and a Larger holed one for your entertainment. I like the large holed one, yet you put the small holed one on you may find it hard to get off.  :)
The slick printed bottom makes i nice area to magic mark your item name on. Real smooth and takes the Sharpie mark real well.
Hope someone finds use of them, as i did.
P.S.  The middle part makes a great glue stick as well.......  :)   you can see i don't throw nothing away.........

description.text:
NOTE these parts are rough at best !! Do not rely on them as the end-all/be-all source for these parts. My intent was to revisit and address the known issues as need and time arose. Sadly neither has. Anyway, there seems to be significant variation in the parts as delivered from the factory, so best bet is to measure your borked pieces and use tinkercad to design new ones for printing, or inkscape for sending an svg to ponoko.com or equiv. Printable pieces to replace the arcylic items for the
"Geeetech Kossel Delta Rostock Mini G2s" Just received my Geeetech G2s Pro Dual today. Forums indicate that certain acrylic pieces are prone to breakage, and no models/plans exist. So wanting to ensure a ready supply of replacement parts, I knocked these out real quick. These parts are measured directly from the acrylic. Larger, generally unprintable pieces are not included (yet). Measurements haven't been validated for accuracy - intended as a 'running start' for if/when I ever need to replace.

title: Kinect to STL sketch for Processing

description.text:
Here's my Processing sketch to interface with the Kinect and capture the depth data and render it as a solid STL file. I've included controls to adjust two thresholds - near and far. This allows you to set up a "Han Solo in carbonite" type effect. 
I am not going to hold your hand through setting up Processing and this write up is In Progress, so if you get frustrated, realize that this might not be for you yet. Until I find a way to streamline posting a standalone application that works (currently it doesn't), this is still only for the persistent.
Until Microsoft publishes the code for their KinectFusion project, this is the best I could do to get a directly printable object without messing around in Blender or MeshLab. It's also my first serious coding effort, so forgive any inelegant code. Yes, the STL files are large (15mb) and the detail is hard for the CupCake to print, but it has the outreach potential for people new to 3D printers to create a unique, personalized object by just posing. Before you ask, the STL doesn't seem to take any less time in skeinforge if you use Blender to remove all duplicate vertices first, so I don't bother.

You will need a Kinect attached to your computer.
I haven't yet exported the processing sketch into a more stand-alone version, so you'll have to deal with running the source code, but that means you can change it and improve it.
This sketch runs inside the Processing environment, which you can download here: http://processing.org/
Then you'll need the libraries my script is dependent on:
ToxicLibs: http://hg.postspectacular.com/toxiclibs/downloads/toxiclibs-complete-0020.zip
PeasyCam: http://mrfeinberg.com/peasycam/peasycam_101.zip
Freenect Library: https://github.com/diwi/dLibs/archives/dLibs And also install the OpenKinect drivers to let your computer talk to your Kinect. You'll need to choose the right option for your operating system: http://openkinect.org/wiki/Main_Page Once you have it all set up (yes I know it's a bit of a chore, sorry) run the sketch and use "r" and "f" to adjust the red (far) threshold and "g" and "b" to adjust the green (near) threshold. When you are happy, strike a pose and press "s" to output the STL. This can take a while, depending on your computer's speed, but shouldn't take longer than 5 minutes for the highest resolution setting on a netbook and should be way faster on almost anything else.

description.text:
Quick and easy tool that will making tapping holes in your printed parts much easier! Holds a variety of small thread taps. These things are readily available at most hardware stores, but why spend the gas and few dollars when you can print one out in 20 minutes? Plus you'd be missing out on my Tri-Lobe™ Comfort handle (patent pending). 
Sadly, you have to tap three holes for it to work...use a pair of pliers I guess. it will be the last time you have to, I promise! Sized for 6-32 bolts, but M5 should work too. Two should be tightened until the bottoms are flush with the inside of the tool, these provide a wedge for locking the tap in place with the third. Why is there only one in the picture though? I cheated, used set screws I had lying around for the other two.

I can't believe the years I've snowboarded without taking better care of my knees when riding the gondola! I ski in Eldora, Colorado and there, the lifts take a long time to get to the top of the slopes - so, my right knee (cuz I'm goofy-foot) always feels stressed from having my snowboard dangle at an awkward angle the entire trip up. Well, be sore no more... and SOAR! (sorry!) Use this simple hook, in combination with a 12 inch segment of rope (plus or minus a few inches, depending on your size) and a carabiner - and you'll be able to comfortably carve the slopes all day long, knee-pain free! Carabiner end secures to a loop in your garment (I use the ringlet for gloves on my ski vest) and hook the other end to the board - and relax as you ascend to your next trailhead in comfort. Give it a try - I think you'll be very glad you did. :) Feel free to check out my other designs which are as diverse as they are many: http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs January 14th, 2016 update: Added a Version 3 - this one is neither too long nor too short and has a reinforced hook so it'll be harder to break. I was thinking of kickstarting this idea - if you have any feedback, please be sure to share!

comments.text: I can't wait to try this, I am just comping back from a sprained ankle (my right ankle) and being goofy footed lifts put lots of stress on it. I am going to print this as soon as I get home!

comments.text: Not in Eldora - they just have hanging chairs (per the photo).  Nicer places like Winterpark and Aspen have fast lifts with the foot rests... Eldora may be cheaper, but comes with other 'costs' - hence the reason why I designed this lovely gizmo.

comments.author: GetLoFi

comments.text: I put sound-absorbing sponge inside the spiral section of the speaker housing. Owing to the absorption of the sound generated from the rear side of the speaker cone, crystal clear sound generated from the front side of the speaker cone is experienced.
comments.author: GetLoFi

comments.text: What about Bass?
comments.author: Shine3D

comments.text: The Altec Lansing 1-inch speaker unit has quite good bass performance despite its small size and low cost (US$1 each), but you would not expect it to act as a sub-woofer. After being assembled into the housing, it shows no sign of suppressed bass. I drive it with a small audio amplifier as a tiny desktop sound system for my PC and enjoy it a lot.

author: xzivr

title: Deck and Piece Holder for Steampunk Rally Board Game
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I am in no way affiliated with the company/makers of this game. Just a fan that wanted a way to sort all of my pieces. I recently got a game called Steampunk Rally. I REALLY liked the game, but wasn't a big fan of using ziplock baggies to sort everything out. I hopped into Inventor and built out some pieces to help me sort my box out. The piece holder works great and I also store the character piece holders in with the 10 cog gear when storing everything away. I don't have any finished dice holders because the my printer jammed during the overnight print and I haven't gotten back to printing them out. I figured dice in a bag wasn't too bad... I also saw some cool chests that store 36 x 6-sided dice, so maybe I will come back and do a cog variant to match the game. I was trying to build stuff with size limitations of the box in mind so these dice holders should carry dice and fit in box perfectly if you print out a set (let me know how it goes if I don't update this). I only needed 3 deck lids printed because I have 4 of my decks put into 2 stacks (bottoms have a chamfer to fit in snug). The game has 5 decks, 4 for actual gameplay use and a fifth is just character cards. I think I might paint these pieces up in a bronze/copper to match the theme.

This is a case for a Raspberry pi in the shape of an NES (Nintendo Entertainment System). It was inspired by the Mini (NES). It is designed to have a functioning lid that allows access to the SD card of the RasPi. I don't have a working 3d printer yet or a RasPi so I can not vouch for how well it will print. Give it a try and let me know if it works.

description.text:
Printing this now.  I'll post pics if it turns out...  or not.
So far it's looking good.

Ran a little tight I like the print, but it is a little tight. It was just barely too tight though. I cracked the bottom (smaller) side of the case when I was fitting it. I recommend trimming more of that material back or building slightly scaled up. So close. It was about a mm thinner than the phone, so I'll move that out. I'm also going to enlarge the "Seattle" so that prints better. I may enlarge the logo as well.

comments.text: I used full support and removed the scaffolding after it printed.  The logo was on the 'top' side as it printed.  I did not finish work (sanding, shaping, painting) on the outside of the case in the pictures.  I'm finding that printing this at about 107% fits pretty well with some shaping inside.

title: 7mm SSD case for StarTech SATA to USB adapter

description.header: 7mm SSD case for StarTech SATA to USB adapter
description.text: Converts a laptop 7mm SSD and SATA to USB adapter into a portable, external media device! Works well for media, clumsy folks who don't want to break a hard drive, and portable Linux installations.

• 7mm SSD. Any drive should work, but I used a SanDisk Plus SSD.
  • This SATA to USB adapter: http://www.amazon.com/StarTech-SATA-Drive-Adapter-Cable/dp/B00HJZJI84
  • A 3D Printer
  • Time

• Pre rendered standard SSD sizes
    • 120GB
    • 128GB
    • 240GB
    • 256GB
    • 480GB
    • 512GB
    • and a text-less version.
  • Clip so the SSD does not fall out the bottom
  • Finger cut out for easy accessibility
  • Sturdy, 4 perimeter design.
  • And a hole for the access indicator!

Simply remove extra bits and strands of filiment. If the SSD is too loose, surround the SSD with some paper. This will not only protect the SSD from the scratchy plastic, but also provide a nice snug fit inside the case.

• Connect the SSD to the adapter.
  • Slide the USB cable end through the case
  • Pull the USB cable through the case
  • Align the SSD (optional: surrounded with paper) so it fits in the hole
  • Push the SSD through the large hole until it hits the other end of the case
  • Attach the clip (if needed) to the bottom of the case
Inventor 2016 Pro You can download the *.ipt (source) and modify the text and/or dimensions of the model.

小型H-Botタイプの3Dプリンタです。
筐体は2020アルミフレーム材使用(150Lx8、190Lx4)接続はアングルブラケット使用(x12)
モータはNEMA17サイズx4
プーリは2GT、Z20x3
X軸ガイドシャフトφ4x155Lx2
Y軸ガイドシャフトφ4ｘ150Lx2
Z軸ガイドシャフトφ6x150Lx2
ヘッド冷却ファンは2510サイズファン
原点スイッチはOMRON D2FC-F-7Nx3
ホットエンドは完全オリジナルタイプ（ヒータは12V20Wタイプ)
ベッドはアクリル板(t2)で取外し可能
ベッドのレベリングはmarlinのマニュアルベッドレベリング機構を使用(LCDメニューより実行)
DISCOUNT SMART CONTROLLER使用(ベッドレベリング動作させる為に必要)
ドライブギアはMK8 DriveGear
ガイドベアリングは623ZZ、軸は平行ピン3x10L
スライド部軸受け及びアイドラは、NTN製R-MLEベアリング若しくはOILES製LFブッシュ(ドライメッシュ)使用(0408x20及び0610x4、アイドラの軸は平行ピン04x16Lx10)使用 ブッシュ及び平行ピン取付部はプリント後にドリル又はリーマを使用して穴径を合わせる事
ネジ締め込み部はプリント後にタップにてネジ切りをする事(リミットスイッチのネジはM1.4の為、1mmドリルにて下穴加工後、そのままネジを締め込み)
造形範囲は108x71x103mm 後の詳細は気が向いたら追記σ(^◇^;) 本機使用のテストプリントサンプル

description.text:
This is bowden extruder which can adjust tension of spring easily with M3 allen wrench.
It is for MK7 drive gear and 688ZZ(8x16x5) bearing. It uses fitting from E3D v6 hotend as bowden tube insert fitting, easy to use and looks simple. Filament is guided all the way through inside extruder, to prevent possible stuck inside. As for the spring, I use 25mm length of OD 8.2/ID 6.2. You might need stronger spring to have more grip in high speed printing. Four 30mm M3 bolts (or Three 30mm and One 25mm) are needed for assembly It has 21mm thick and designed to mount on the wall, I mounted it on 5mm acrylic frame. If you want to mount thick wall or bracket, you would need longer bolts. I have used this extruder more than 3 weeks without any problem.
Hopefully you enjoy it. EDIT:01/08/2016
I found stronger spring is needed for higher speed (>100mm/s). UPDATE:
I uploaded solidworks source files.(extruder-MK7.zip)
Feel free modify as you want.

Printer:

DIY H-bot

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30% or higher

I am inspired by Ultimaker 2 feeder.
I wanted it looks simple and it's tension be adjustable

Made to fit the horizon hobby micro fpv camera and add protection ageist crashes.
Installation is very easy simply unscrew the lens and insert the body in to the case then screw the lens back on. then use a small rubber band to secure the back.
Note: the lens hole may need a small amount of plastic shaved off depending on the printers accuracy.
